texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Making Java keystores at the same time as you create a CSR and key is pretty easy, but if you have a pre-made private key that you want to throw into a keystore, it can be difficult. However, follow these steps and you'll ber done quickly!
texts.text: Making Java keystores at the same time as you create a CSR and key is pretty easy, but if you have a pre-made private key that you want to throw into a keystore, it can be difficult. However, follow these steps and you'll ber done quickly!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Save the new certificate to server.crt and the new key to server.key. If intermediate certificates are necessary, then place all of the certificates into a file called cacert.crt. Now, you will have to make a PKCS #12 file:
texts.text: Save the new certificate to server.crt and the new key to server.key. If intermediate certificates are necessary, then place all of the certificates into a file called cacert.crt. Now, you will have to make a PKCS #12 file:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
openssl pkcs12 -export -inkey server.key -in server.crt \
    -name tomcat-domain.com -certfile cacert.crt -out domain.com.p12
texts.text:
openssl pkcs12 -export -inkey server.key -in server.crt \
    -name tomcat-domain.com -certfile cacert.crt -out domain.com.p12

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: To perform the rest of the work, you will need a copy of the KeyTool GUI. In the GUI, make a new keystore in JKS format. Import the PKCS #12 key pair, and save the keystore as a JKS. Upload the keystore to the server and then configure the keystore within Tomcat/JBoss.
texts.text: To perform the rest of the work, you will need a copy of the KeyTool GUI. In the GUI, make a new keystore in JKS format. Import the PKCS #12 key pair, and save the keystore as a JKS. Upload the keystore to the server and then configure the keystore within Tomcat/JBoss.
